Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Multinuclear 500 MHz NMR Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI), the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF), and EPSCoR programs, Professor Jessie Carrick from Tennessee Technological University and colleagues Daniel Swartling, Jeffrey Rice, William Carroll and Xuanzhi Zhan will acquire a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer equipped with a broadband nitrogen-cooled cryoprobe. This spectrometer will allow research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as allow study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The nitrogen-cooled probe will provide a significant increase in sensitivity relative to standard NMR probes. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research performed by undergraduate and graduate students. The new instrument will have a significant and immediate impact on the research training and teaching endeavors of faculty in the departments of Chemistry as well as Chemical Engineering and an interdisciplinary Environmental Sciences Program. The presence of a reliable instrument equipped with a sample changer will allow much greater student access to a spectrometer in the teaching laboratories than an old, low-field instrument currently at this university. The PIs indicate that the instrument will be utilized by students in the sophomore organic courses, the advanced analytical laboratory, and an advanced organic spectroscopy course. Special emphasis will be directed to women and other historically underrepresented students in STEM.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) synthesizing bis-1,2,4-triazine ligands, including conformational and subsequent complexation studies with simulated actinides for potential remediation of used nuclear fuel; (b) structurally characterizing fluorescent proteins for nerve regeneration and wound healing; (c) developing solution phase structure approaches for dynamic molecules; (d) studying conformations of arrestin proteins; (e) developing green chemistry methodology; and (f) studying thiosemicarbazone ligands as potential anti-cancer therapeutics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tennessee Technological University (TTU) is a comprehensive, public institution of higher learning founded in 1915 and located in Cookeville, TN.  TTU is a doctoral university with moderate research activity according to Carnegie classification. The university was awarded a grant through the NSF MRI program, award number 1531870, in the amount of $586,400 for a proposal entitled: Acquisition of a Multinuclear 500 MHz NMR Spectrometer to obtain a replacement for the university’s previous 17-year old Varian 300 MHz NMR spectrometer in August 2015. Prior to the award, faculty and students routinely relied on spectroscopic resources at other regional institutions which required travel or shipment of samples off campus just to perform routine structural characterization in support of ongoing research projects. Sourcing of the instrument and completion of necessary procurement procedures was completed during fall 2015. Minor room renovations were completed early spring 2016. The NMR spectrometer was delivered, installed, and qualified for use in June 2016 and has been available for continuous use by university faculty, staff, and students since that time.  Research in the areas of organic synthesis of novel ligands for liquid-liquid separations, structural determination approaches of dynamic molecules in solution through the use of residual dipolar couplings, conformational studies of arrestin proteins, as well as development of greener synthetic strategies to active pharmaceutical ingredients was supported and expanded during the award period. To date, 77 total users including undergraduate, masters, and doctoral students in chemistry, biochemistry, and chemical engineering, as well as university faculty, have been trained in basic instrument operation and data acquisition. TTU student trainees whose research utilized NMR spectroscopy have matriculated to seven Ph.D. programs in chemistry or chemical engineering, in addition to medical school, during the three-year award period.  Acquisition of this instrument has had far reaching broader impacts in the improvement in delivery of course content at TTU. The NMR spectrometer has substantively modernized and strengthened an experiential laboratory course in spectroscopic identification of organic compounds which is a co-listed course at the graduate and undergraduate levels. Further, students in the introductory organic and organic chemistry course sequences have benefitted from real world examples of spectroscopic data presented in lecture and laboratory courses that was made possible by the award. Quantifiable deliverables related to research over the approximate two years post installation have resulted in the publishing of nine scientific manuscripts in high impact, peer-reviewed scientific journals, relating to the projects described above, as well as, 36 external presentations which disseminated results procured from NMR spectroscopy experiments by TTU students presented throughout the U.S.  Research results from the separations project supported by this NSF award facilitated an external research award from the U.S. Department of Energy to study compounds that have potential to decrease the long term radiotoxicity of spent nuclear fuel from legacy waste and as a byproduct of energy production.  In summary, TTU has significantly improved the depth of research productivity and student training as a direct result of this NSF award.
